MEME
Who is Buzz Lightyear?  We know of The Space Ranger, the Team Leader, the Toy from Andy‚Äôs childhood, the one foretold by Martian myths and legends.  But then who *is* Buzz Lightyear?  Is he the kind of man who dreamed of going to space, to be the first of many to set out and meet other life forms?  Is he a soldier who does what he‚Äôs told, but acts out if his heart says otherwise?  Or is he just a man like any other?  These are the questions I have after seeing this. Chris Evans was announced to have been cast as the human Buzz Lightyear upon the project's announcement in December 2020. Evans was the first and only choice MacLane had for Buzz. Buzz would be travelling at about 99.999999999819% of the speed of light, which is about 299,792,457.9994574 m/s. The speed of light is 299,792,458 m/s. Then in the 90s. within this animated Toy Story universe, an "animated" Buzz Lightyear show was made (the one we, in this universe, saw in the form of "Buzz Lightyear of Star Command, came out in 2000 and had four seasons.) and the toy Andy has was based on THAT show. Meanwhile, Andy in present day watches a "reboot" of Buzz Lightyear, in theaters, live action (in the Toy Story universe), and  that is what THIS is. Oh that's right! It was because they decided to raise the admission fees to all of their parts just before the attraction opened. Having watched this trailer far too much I think I am willing to place money on the plot of this movie being time dilation, similar in concept to how Interstellar showed the astronauts struggling to reconcile how their hours of percieved time had translated to decades on earth. At 1 minute in you can see what I can only assume to be the same launch tower we see in the very first scene, except built up to a frankly absurd scale. Something o that size seems like it must have taken at least a good few years of constant work, if not longer.  Edit: I guess this isnt actually as shocking a reveal as I might make it seem, given how the whiteboard shown at 1:08 quite clearly states the Buzz will experience time dilation that will make his seemingly short trip take years on earth. I imagine this will be a constant presence rather than something only touched on a bit.

This feels kinda uncanny valley-ish tbh. Buzz in particular, he feels too weird-looking in this hyperrealistic setup...  I think I prefer the bright and colorful designs of the old cartoon better, they feel like they actually match a character connected to Toy Story-- this feels like a space adventure that just so happens to include a TS character. It feels just. so weird. If they wanted to do an original story (the cartoon could be WEIRD so I dont mind scrapping it, tho I'm still very fond of the opening movie), I think making some sort of stylized style like Luca did would have been better. It also feels so wrong to have someone else voicing Buzz. Nothing against Evans, he's a great guy, but he doesn't have that grand, almost pompous voice Buzz is known for. Idk... Might watch this dubbed in my country and pray that the OG Buzz dub guy voices him. But this doesn't really interest me much really. This actually looks good, definitely seems like one of the more serious Pixar films. The shots look really nice, and I think Chris Evans actually fits as a younger Buzz Lightyear. If Tim Allen wasn‚Äôt recast due to his political views, then he could play an older, more experienced Buzz in the future. The only thing I feel is off is the green and purple in Buzz‚Äôs suit, it doesn‚Äôt fit with the film‚Äôs tone and feel, and looks too silly. I think it would have made more sense if it was replaced with Black and Grey, and then in the Toy Story universe once they made the toy and Star Command cartoon, they made his suit Green and Purple to make it more vibrant and appealing towards kids. There‚Äôs also a lot of confusion on how this film connects to the Toy Story universe, as some think it‚Äôs an event that happened there, though, that‚Äôs not the case. This film is a fiction film created in the Toy Story universe, that Pixar decided to make a reality. Basically, the Buzz Lightyear toy was based off of this Big Blockbuster Movie (Also because of how modern it looks, my head canon is that it‚Äôs a remake of that original film)

So he‚Äôs supposed to use hyper drive which will let him travel to a distant star, he‚Äôs then supposed to slingshot around this Star and head back, and once he approaches the planet again he needs to send the ship through some hoops to stay in the correct flight path. I have a theory for this movie. It might pull a little bit of an Interstellar on us. Buzz's dad is an astronaut. He goes up on a mission which ends up hurtling him into deep space. Buzz is now following in his dad's footsteps, training at the acadamy for years, just like his father. There's a new mission now, the test of the first space craft with the ability of faster than light travel, thanks to those crystals we see in the trailer, plus star command engineering. Buzz is the best pilot they got, and so he volunteers. He knows this could be his last mission, but that's the risk he is willing to take, to honor his missing father, who is somewhere out there. There might even be a chance he's still alive, although slim. He takes flight. He successfully travels at lightspeed. Little does he know he has traveled centuries into the future, because while to him it looked like no time has passed at all, time went on without him for centuries. Star Command now has colonized worlds beyond the Milkway, but a new threat emerges from the cosmos, a threat that star command is unable to contain: Zurg. Buzz and his team must stop Zurg from destroying star command, for leaving him out there in space so many many centuries ago, for taking him from his only son, Buzz Lightyear

This is a Movie about a Movie about Buzz Lightyear. Then after the release of the successful movie, like all successful franchise movies since Star Wars, they then made toys and other merchandise just like "star wars action figures". And that's how Andy got the toy of Buzz. Cause nothing else would make sense in this context. We're seeing sifi technology well beyond 1995 which is when Andy got Buzz. But leading up to 1995 there were tons of space movies which had miniatures and such to create these sifi worlds in film. Final shot could be Andy and family watching the movie in a theater setting it up for Toy Story 1. Because in Toy Story 1 Andy was obsessed with Buzz, and couldn't believe his Mom could get one since they are all sold out. Why would a random toy be sold out and have commercials about it on TV (from the movie) if it wasn't for immense popularity from a new Movie starring Buzz Lightyear. Which is where Andy would get the obsession to want Buzz in the first place after seeing his movie in a theater. Also what else could the plot be if it's suppose to be tied back to Toy Story, I mean honestly.

So let me debrief this like the total nerd I am.   1.) 0:12 "Do you people still use fossil fuels, or have you discovered crystallic fusion?" This is obviously a nod back to the first Toy Story movie when Buzz is working on fixing his ship and asks Woody about the energy source they use. Thus here we finally see what crystallic fusion actually is. Besides I can't help but notice it looks very similar to the kyber crystals in Star Wars...  2.) 0:17 This is an obvious one but the ship is obviously the same design like the ship packaging that Buzz is stored in the Toy Story films when bought from the store.  3.) 0:38 Buzz is obviously the actual name of the person but we can see here that they are on a mission travelling lightyears into space thus probably where the other name came from.  4.) 0:57 Star Wars Dagobah reference.  5.) 1:07 Similar reaction happens in "Captain Marvel" where the "cat" is not all it seems and is well a flerken.  6.) 1:15 Listen to the song: "Let the children lose it, let the children use it." A reference to what eventually happens to Toys and ironically "Buzz" as we know him is in fact a toy. Kind of ironic actually.  7.) 1:17 Zurg's troops from the opening scene of "Toy Story 2" all lined up like stormtroopers awaiting their emperor...  8.) 1:19 Okay well we all know that we think that this is Zurg because of thw aesthetic.  9.) 1:20 Okay we all know what that suit is and it looks neat!  10.) 1:30 WHY?! YOU SHOULD'VE FINISHED THE LINE!!! Oh well.

Our movies look just like real life! @1:09 It looks like it's using physics for gravitational time dilation, although the numbers are vastly simplified. For Buzz, he'll be doing a slingshot turn around the Sun, which has a higher gravitational pull than Earth (due to its mass), thus slowing time for him in comparison to what Earth has, and then arrive in Earth's orbit again after being accelerated to ridiculous speeds, before finally slowing down within those 3 rings.   This could be a little tearjerker, since for Buzz it seems to be only 4 minutes for him, whereas the rest of Earth will have experienced 4 years already. Well, if you've seen Interstellar, then you know what I mean.  Perhaps on the 'future' version of Earth, there will be faster forms of travel for him to go out of the solar system.

So this looks pretty cool, but I feel like it breaks the Toy Story universe. I was always under the impression the toy Buzz Lightyear was based off a television/movie character (like most toys). As far as we're aware the universe of Toy Story is much like our own in terms of technological advancement and contact with alien species.   BUT  If what we're seeing is meant to be the "true" origins of the toy Buzz Lightyear, AND what we're seeing is meant to be "reality" in that universe, then that would imply humans in Toy Story are far more advanced than we are because they're capable of interstellar flight. So why is there no evidence of this in Toy Story? Were these events covered up and this is some sort of top secret mission? But if so why would there be toys made based off this guy?

I‚Äôm‚Ä¶not sure how to feel about this. On one hand, the animation is absolutely stellar, character designs are mostly well done, and, yeah, there is some potential here. On the other hand, taking what was essentially a parody of sci-fi Saturday morning cartoons and morphing it into this more down-to-earth(-ish?), dramatic space thriller feels a bit off-putting. It feels especially weird when I look at Buzz‚Äôs iconic exaggerated head design being paired with this more realistic body shape and the frankly crummy looking Lightyear suit. Also, despite the filmmakers‚Äô best efforts, the whole ‚ÄúDisney nostalgia baiting‚Äù shtick that has been permeating this company for the past decade still rubs me the wrong way.

I want to be excited for something but after the last few years, I just can't get there. I absolutely loved Toy Story as a kid; I was a toddler when it came out. But this just feels unnecessary and redundant... Not to mention the all-too-predictable Bowie song. David Bowie was a real artist and personally I don't enjoy his music being used to promote a kid's film; it's just schlocky to me. It would be like using a Pink Floyd song in the trailer for a Power Rangers movie. It just doesn't jive with me. Anyway, I'll probably get a lot of downvotes if anyone reads this. But seeing all the usual comments, I just felt like giving my 2 cents. Dissenting opinions are okay. Personally, I've been tired of Disney for years (and that goes for all the Marvel movies too).
